content: The "Cardiomyopathy Health Education, Awareness, Risk Assessment, and Training in the Schools (HEARTS) Act of 2011" aims to increase education and awareness of cardiomyopathy among school administrators, educators, and families by providing materials and resources. This includes amending Part P of title III of the Public Health Service Act to add a new section focused on this goal. The "Cardiomyopathy Health Education, Awareness, Risk Assessment, and Training in the Schools (HEARTS) Act of 2011" requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop public education materials on cardiomyopathy for school administrators, educators, and families within 18 months. The "Cardiomyopathy Health Education, Awareness, Risk Assessment, and Training in the Schools (HEARTS) Act of 2011" mandates the development of materials including a risk assessment worksheet, guidelines for defibrillator placement, training on defibrillators and CPR, and recommendations for cardiac emergency response plans in schools and child care centers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is tasked with creating and updating these resources, with the option to establish an advisory panel for input from patient advocacy organizations and medical representatives. The "Cardiomyopathy Health Education, Awareness, Risk Assessment, and Training in the Schools (HEARTS) Act of 2011" requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to collaborate with patient advocacy organizations, medical professionals, CDC representatives, and other federal agencies to develop materials and resources for cardiomyopathy education. These resources will be disseminated to state educational agencies for distribution. State educational agencies will distribute cardiomyopathy education materials, risk assessment worksheets, guidelines, training information, and recommendations to school administrators, educators, health professionals, coaches, parents, guardians, and caregivers. The Secretary will disseminate materials to health departments, pediatricians, hospitals, and other health professionals. The materials will also be posted on the CDC website. The Secretary will disseminate materials to health departments, pediatricians, hospitals, and other health professionals, as well as post them on the CDC website. Public Internet webpages dedicated to cardiomyopathy are encouraged to be created by State educational agencies, with additional information regarding cardiomyopathy provided as deemed appropriate. A report to Congress outlining steps taken to increase public education and awareness of cardiomyopathy must be submitted annually. Cardiomyopathy is defined as a rare heart condition, a disease of the heart muscle. Cardiomyopathy is a rare heart condition affecting the heart muscle, with symptoms varying from no symptoms to fatigue, irregular heartbeats, and potential sudden cardiac death. Types include dilated, hypertrophic, restrictive, arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, and left ventricular noncompaction. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to schools, administrators, and nonprofit organizations specializing in cardiomyopathy. Authorization of Appropriations: $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2013, $750,000 for fiscal year 2014, and $500,000 for each of fiscal years 2015 through 2017 to support research and increase public awareness of cardiomyopathy.
